ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Heavy (virtual) discussion component

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to read, write, and speak basic swahili! was a good course to learn the very basics of swahili and I think I could now survive in an East African country off of just swahili if I needed to!
I learned how to speak introductory Kiswahili.
As with most language courses, you learn the groundwork for the language. You work on basic vocab and grammar rules of Swahili and learn a little bit about life in East Africa.
How to introduce myself and hold a general conversation in Kiswahili. Also a knowledge on the culture and history of the languge.
The foundations of Kiswahili language and East African culture
Foundational language skills in Swahili.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths -- professor clearly cares during class, asks all the student questions, wants to hear about our lives etc. And you learn a fair amount of Swahili through the course of the semester. Definitely know a LOT more now than when I began. 

Weakness - sometimes class was boring. Was a lot of just reading new words on the zoom screen. I know teaching a language virtually was probably very difficult, but i think prof should have livened it up a little if possible.

The structure of the class jumps from topic to topic a little bit, but by and large, I felt like I learned at an extremely accelerated rate, and learned a lot. The class would very clearly be even more fun in person, as the professor has incredible energy, that is surely amplified in real life.

This course was fairly easy to keep up with and I would say it's the biggest strength is Mwalimu. He really makes sure you are keeping up with the class and is very responsive. You get a ton of practice speaking and listening as everyday Mwalimu sets aside time to converse with each student in Swahili. I would say it's the biggest Weakness is it was unorganized. We didn't use the book which made it so if you had a misunderstanding you almost had to email the prof. Also I wasn't totally clear about what work was being graded and what wasn't being graded.
Loved this class. The small size made it really easy to engage in and receive constant feedback. The professor also makes it easy to learn a lot in a short amount of time. No weaknesses.

Beginning Kiswahili I has many strengths. Mwalimu Kiarie is entertaining and effective, he is extremely welcoming and accommodating, and he adapts his course throughout the semester based on how students are doing. He makes sure all of his students develop the most important skills of grammar with hints of what is to come later, he devotes a lot of class time for each student to speak with him one on one in Kiswahili, and he engages everyone in interesting discussions of language and culture. He doesn't assign too much homework and at the same time covers a broad range of elementary Kiswahili grammar and vocabulary, focusing on developing the skills of speaking, writing, and reading.

The course had a lot of flexibility built in, but sometimes I wished that there were more structure. We read from a textbook that Mwalimu is developing from time to time, but it was difficult to tell what topic we would learn next. Our vocabulary lists were impressively extensive, but I would appreciate learning more of the most functional words; for example, we could say "avocado" (parachichi) but we had to ask him how to say "to be able to, can" (kuweza) (and if you didn't write it down then, you would have to ask again) -- although I suppose in the end I did learn both. I also would have appreciated more frequent, shorter assessments, because studying for quizzes and tests really helped me solidify what we had covered. The tests could run a bit long, especially if we hadn't had one in a while, and what was expected of us on tests was not always clear (for example, you could lose points for not writing enough on a free response question, but there was no minimum number of words specified).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Weakness -- just presenting random words on the zoom board ... maybe improve other involvement on zoom ?

This semester went much better than I thought. I really liked how he talked to each of us personally before we jumped into the lesson. I think it was a good way to start the course and really got me engaged.

The things that kept me most engaged were when we had discussions in class about East African culture. I thought some of the discussions and/or reviews on grammar could have been assigned as readings from the textbook to do outside of class in order to maximize in-class time and engagement.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would if you want to learn Swahili! It's not a work intensive course, and it's easy to get involved, learn Kiswahili, and not be stressed while doing.
If you are interested in learning Swahili, this is a fantastic class. I learned so much, and was blown away by the language.
Yes. I really enjoyed this class. The professor is great, and it is also great to dive into a "non-traditional" language and learn something out of my comfort zone.
If you are interested in learning a new language in an easy class with a very fun professor then yes!
I highly recommend Kiswahili. It's a fascinating language and Mwalimu Kiarie is an excellent teacher.
Yes! It was an excellent introductory course to Swahili. Professor WaNjogu was engaging, available to answer questions, and provided a lot of opportunities to speak and write in Swahili.

extras.title:
SWAH 610 01/SWAH 110 01
        Beginning Kiswahili I/Elementary Kiswahili I
